text: for the last 10 days this small yellow
triangle has offered the best hope for
finding flight mh370 but today came the
announcement that the pinger locator is
coming out of the water the attempt to
detect pings from the planes black boxes
is over the australian defence vessel
ocean shield will see searching with the
toad pinger locator later today and
deploy the autonomous underwater vehicle
blue thin 21 as soon as possible tell
girls wiggle and everything looks good
here the bluefin 21 is in fact a large
yellow torpedo-like vehicle starting
tonight it will be sent down four and a
half thousand meters to the bottom of
the Indian Ocean there it will fly
slowly back and forth using high-powered
sonar to map the ocean floor below it
travels at barely more than walking pace
no one is now pretending this will be
quick or easy when they picked up the
sound of the pingers last week there was
a real sense of expectation here that
they were about to find the plane but
then the pings stopped and they've heard
nothing for the last six days so now
they have no choice but to start the
long laborious process of mapping the
ocean floor using sonar that could take
weeks months or even years the search
for the missing plane did get one small
break today the searchers have found an
oil slick on the ocean surface just to
the south of where they picked up the
pings last week it may be nothing but if
it does turn out to be aviation fuel
this could be more good evidence that
they are at least searching in the right
area Rupert Wingfield Hayes BBC News in
Perth
